comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I suspect this might be Alexis Albert and perhaps his father Frank. Here's a 1933 pic of Alexis Albert and his then fiancee Elsie...almost looks as if it could have been taken on this same occasion nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17017783

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Well spotted! You may be right about it being taken on the same occasion. This could then provide a date for our other RSYS pics, incl this one: This would certainly be pre 1934 (i.e. when Carment died).
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] P.S. Check out this article...methinks I spot Frank Albert! :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes...that's got to be him! My guess is that the pic of Frank and Alexis Albert and the pic of David Carment, Justice Alf Backhouse (and ? their wives) were probably taken on the same occasion...my hunch is the mid to later 1920s...after doing a bit more research, I now suspect the 1933 SMH pic of Alexis Albert and his fiancee Elsie might have been taken on a later occasion...Elizabeth Carment died in 1931 (I gather she's the woman we see in the pic 00024214 with her husband David and ?Mrs Kate Backhouse and Justice Alfred Backhouse)...regardless of when they were taken, they're wonderful pics..

Just out of interest, are they Sam Hood's numbers on the pics?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] PS...that's a fantastic piece on the Rawhiti. Not sure I could handle the colour scheme though! Pink and green!!!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] We had initially thought 1920s too, but for a completely different reason, that is the women's clothing. FYI, we have had word from relatives of David and Elizabeth Carment that the woman to his left is not Elizabeth unfortunately. The numbers below right are the museum's object numbers by the way. It's a very interesting article! Also, if you're interested, the Vaughan Evans Library holds a digitised collection of the Australian Motor Boating and Yachting Monthly.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] That's really good to have the info that my guess re Elizabeth Carment was wrong. Just shows how careful you've got to be when trying to identify people in these pics...how easy it is to go off on a tangent guessing and get things completely wrong. 

Thanks for the links to the magazines. Given my interest in the history of leisure and the emergence of specialist leisure pursuits, I find these magazines really interesting.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] But it was a good guess nonetheless, she looks about the right age and it is often a fair assumption to make. :) That's ok, didn't know that was your area of interest, we'll get to uploading more of that sort of content here on Flickr to pique your interest! Also, check out eMuseum Sport and Lifestyle section for a range of objects from our collection.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] oooh that's a good one!!! Thanks quasymody. No doubt there will be many discoveries to be had in the NLA's Fairfax collection!
